this changes w.r.t. master which had

  running_time - now > time_per_request

so running time is the start of the next interval rather than end of next interval

the implementation on master leads to 'bunching' behaviour as demonstrated by the test in test_slo:

  * assume the max_rate is 1 per sec, running_time is initially 0
  * a request made at say t=99 is granted immediately and 
    running_time is set to 100
  * a request at any time in the second preceding running_time, 
    including t=99, would be granted without sleeping
  * running time is incremented by 1 second to 101
  * a next request at t<100 would then sleep until 101
  * running time is incremented by 1 second to 102
  * a next request at 101 would be granted without sleeping
  * running time is incremented by 1 second to 103
  * a next request at 101.99 would sleep until 103

e.g.

  * requests made at    99, 99.01,  99.99, 101, 101.99 
  * requests granted at 99, 99.01, 101,    101, 103

The change here means that for the same requests:

  * requests made at    99,  99.01, 100, 101, 102 
  * requests granted at 99, 100,    101, 102, 103

cinder/templates/cron-job-cinder-volume-.message: Why is both certificates and dbTlsSecret checking required everywhere. Can you think of case where certificates is true and there will be no secret for database? If this can happen then we are already in trouble.

`manifests.certificates` assumes that the database TLS secret is set (let alone set properly), but that secret is created as part of another chart's scope and, unless value overrides are used consistently, there's a chance of the secret's name not being populated.

While we can't easily defend against improperly set values at render time, we can at least do a simple null check for it's population.

I agree with you but in the case as well if TLS secret is not set we are not throwing error, we are moving along assuming TLS is not enabled. In this case the deployment will still fail because in many places when certificates is true it assumes proper configuration has been provided. As you rightly said "we can't easily defend against improperly set values at render time". Even if we pass here, we will fail somewhere else.

cinder/templates/job-bootstrap.yaml.message:
Not sure what value is this adding. If this is not there, our system is already messed up and the deployment needs to be fixed. If we pass here the Kubernetes deployment will fail anyways.
This is true for the check that you have added everywhere.

This is another null check, since the Keystone-related secret (https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/openstack-helm/+/refs/heads/master/cinder/templates/secret-keystone.yaml) is populated based on these lines:
- `{{- $userContext := index $context.Values.endpoints.identity.auth $userClass }}` (https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/+/refs/heads/master/helm-toolkit/templates/snippets/_keystone_secret_openrc.tpl#19)
- `{{- if $userContext.cacert }}` (https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/+/refs/heads/master/helm-toolkit/templates/snippets/_keystone_secret_openrc.tpl#29)

That secret is then used in this bootstrap job:
- `{{- with $env := dict "ksUserSecret" ( index $envAll.Values.secrets.identity $keystoneUser ) "useCA" (ne $tlsSecret "") }}` (https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/+/refs/heads/master/helm-toolkit/templates/manifests/_job-bootstrap.tpl#82)
- https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/+/refs/heads/master/helm-toolkit/templates/snippets/_keystone_openrc_env_vars.tpl#135

Especially `_job-bootstrap.tpl`'s L82 condition for populating `OS_CACERT` relies on the secret *just* existing and not on the condition specified in `_keystone_secret_openrc.tpl`'s L29 used to define the `OS_CACERT` field based on `cacert`'s value.

This means that, before this check, the bootstrap job will *always* attempt to use `OS_CACERT` from the Keystone secret, regardless of whether that key is actually defined there.

doc/source/developer/specs/global-semaph.message:
Sorry, I was trying to convey that the in-repo semaphore would cause a configuration error which means that the config object would not be loaded; therefore any jobs that referenced that semaphore name would get the global one.

In other words, if you start with an in-repo semaphore "foo" and use it in jobs, then add a global semaphore "foo" then as soon as you do that, you get a config error and also the jobs continue to run but using the global semaphore.
These two sentences are a bit ambiguous to me. If this is a configuration error then why would one or the other take precedence. It should just fail to exist entirely instead?
Ya, that makes sense. I guess that means jobs don't automatically fail but you may have more contention for the semaphore in which case having an error is helpful.

By taking a deeper look, We are trying to minimize the duplication or job parenting.

But I think it will not work. If we take a deeper look at zuul multi parenting jobs.

We have -options jobs https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/src/branch/master/zuul.d/standalone-jobs.yaml#L405
```
- job:
    name: tripleo-ci-scenario000-standalone-options
    vars:
      featureset: '052'
      featureset_override:
        standalone_environment_files:
          - 'environments/low-memory-usage.yaml'
          - 'ci/environments/scenario000-standalone.yaml'
        tempest_services:
          - keystone
        tempest_run_concurrency: 1
        tempest_tempest_conf_overrides:
          'auth.tempest_roles': "Member"
        tempest_test_whitelist:
          - 'keystone_tempest_plugin.tests.api.identity.v3'
```

It does not have any parent and it works well when we use it as a parent in dependent job
```
- job:
    name: tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-standalone
    parent: tripleo-ci-scenario000-standalone-options
```

and then we create another child job (tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-standalone) by using parent which is inherited or using different parent.

````
- job:
    name: tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-standalone
    voting: true
    parent: tripleo-ci-base-standalone-centos-8
    branches: stable/train
````
For example tripleo-ci-base-standalone-centos-8 parent is tripleo-ci-base-required-projects-standalone-upstream.

and tripleo-ci-base-required-projects-standalone-upstream job properties does not exist downstream that's why it is not working.

I think we should simply using multiparenting and keep options seperate so that it will be re-used downstream.

Additional vars or zuul job attibute needs to be added in the job where parent is coming from another parent otherwise it will give zuul config error issue.

Hi Ian, thanks for the feedback.

For me I felt that the Ubuntu element was the most natural place for this change as it pertains directly to the Ubuntu install and I believe that cloud-init comes in with the Ubuntu image here.
Additionally, it preserves the functioning of the DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR arg (at least if you are using it to propagate mirrors to the image, not just in the build), which is set on this element. I did consider adding it to the apt-sources element, but decided against it as it was not specific to that element.

Cheers,

Hey Marios, thanks for the review, I'm not a huge fan of regex too, however, this was the only way to retrieve this kind of data as the pattern of running the containers entrypoint changed over the time.
Anyway, you're right about having a set_fact, but that debug statement is something disabled in a production environment and never executed: we turn it on when we need to collect additional data (-vvvvv) on a CI scenario or for debugging purposes.
This means that in theory, assuming tripleo_cephadm_verbose is set to False, we're saving a task w/o an additional "set_fact".
I can add a set_fact, it doesn't hurt for sure, but in general we try to avoid setting facts when possible and just rely on filters and vars passed to the task.

There's probably way more.  If the process is the painful point here, I think the foundation staff expressed that they would take that on in order to conserve the marketing "terminology", which is a huge oversight by the technical committee IMHO.

The process isn't perfect, there won't be a perfect process.  but, I think this is worse than a less-than-perfect process.
agree with ideas as discussed in PTG, one comment to explain the reason.

That is also one option we can try, but we tried to limit the scope with few of the proposal I listed in 'Tried to solve it in many ways' section like 'name on major city', 'movies' etc and it did not went through. 

I feel any process, schema we use as long as we open those name selection/nomination etc to community we are going to have the issue. And selecting the name without consultation/informing the community also does not feel good to me(maybe it's just me and this might be ok to do).

I myself do not want to drop name and for that reason I volunteer to drive the process for couple of cycle but by seeing its benefits vs problem and time it cause
I thought that is best way to do.

I wish to keep release names too but I agree that the level of unrest and effort spent on it as a result has been excessive. As for why other projects are able to have release names successfully, I think it's likely because their naming scheme limits the possibilities for names. Ubuntu uses "Adjective Animal" and Ceph uses only/mostly words related to octopus or ocean, for example.

As I see it, the thing that needs to be solved is, how to avoid anyone having a serious issue with the name. Could we limit the scope of possible names to be more like Ubuntu and Ceph to "hopefully" avoid controversies in the future? Could the community agree on such a theme if so? This I don't know.

So, as much as I don't like to lose release names, I sympathize with the TC who has had to spend significant energy on naming controversies.

I stand by my points and I think the Debian community is probably way bigger and they still manage to get a name out.

There will be some people who will be unhappy.  There's way more people that will be unhappy if the release names go.

yeah, agree that they have name system but I am not sure how many culture/international communities or number of contributors are involved in those communities. I think that is the key here, big communities like OpenStack are more chance having such issues.

I feel keeping name are more problematic then dropping, it hardly matter what process we use or who select the name. Either foundation does, it will not solve the current problem we have (I have added those in review).

I will be more happy to know how foundation or any other team taking these naming process will solve the problem which TC is not able to do.

That's true that there are big projects which are naming their releases. But on the other hand there are also huge open source projects which don't have any "marketing" names (or I don't know about them at all) and are still doing fine, like e.g. Firefox, Chromium, Linux Kernel (ok, it has some names too but I don't think it's really well known and widely used), Fedora and  probably many others.

That is true, I did see the "cities" and "movies" ideas from the past. Those two IMHO are things that can pretty easily reference some kind of culture/history/politics and have a higher chance of being controversial. It's not like types of animals or types of trees or types of gemstones, for example. Speaking of animals, I was looking forward to Aardvark :)

Yeah, TBH when the idea of selecting the name without consultation of the entire community was first suggested in the past, it felt exclusive in comparison to the prior open nomination and vote. It's all relative. Personally, at this stage I would rather have someone select names without any input over not having any names at all. And I think the foundation would be well suited for selecting names as they are the ones who know the marketing.

I hear you. That is why I won't vote -1 on this because I have seen the problems the TC has had to manage and am understanding to the idea of moving away from naming.

yes, we are not denying that. What we are saying that we have to see both side of it, pros and cons and by seeing all the problem we are facing since long, it is clear that name are more problematic than its benefits.

reference/release-naming.rst.message: Lack of numbers weren't causing problems with choosing release names either, after all, release name choosing problems were independent of the presence or absence of version numbers. This would be more clearly phrased as, "It's an unambiguous way to identify OpenStack releases, and avoids release naming problems by not having release names."

I added the cases where community raised the issues.

We had these issue when we had community voting or TC voting only so that hardly matter. overall I am saying it does not matter which process you use to select name or who select the name, *name* will be problematic.

Hi Ghanshyam, slawek, TC members - I'm sorry I didn't show up in the room where this discussion happened at the Project Teams Gathering - you know how busy PTG gets, and not everyone interested can make it into a room due to project discussions that happen in parallel. 


I strongly object to this wearing my community mentor hat and my community leader and member hat. The release naming process may have its flaws. However, we've persisted. Alphabetically named releases are an attractive feature of this community to new contributors. I've had many 1x1 discussions and can attest to how new contributors enjoy working on a release with a code name, and appreciate the storied relevance of the names democratically chosen by the community.  

I would like to know where the problems you mentioned were raised with the wider community. 


> We are a wider community with many international communities, developers, and cultures and choosing a perfect name satisfying all of them is not possible.

This is where community voting would help (not TC voting, let us revert to community voting - would you like to run a poll?). I understand there were disagreements in the past; but, could we just tag them as hiccups? Can we introduce a way to record -1 votes with publicly visible reasons and use that as a way to hear other community members' views about a name? 


> We as individuals also have some problems with a few names which might be due to emotions. politically, or historically. And filtering them is not possible.

allowing people to promote/demote names with explanation prior to a formal vote will allow filtering organically. The foundation does legal checks anyway.. why is this a problem?

> Name after election need trademark checks from the foundation as a final step and there is always a chance that winning names are filtered out so the electorate might not be happy with that. So the process is also not perfect.

but, the electorate has lived with it - it's the reality of trademarking processes... why throw the baby out with the bath water here?

Also, let's add a detailed explanation about what problem we faced in the 'release name' process and why we are dropping it so that in future we know what we are going to bring all these roblemes back if we think of release name again.

Why we dropped the release name:
--------------------------------

Problem with release name:
``````````````````````````
- We are a wider community with many international communities, developers, and cultures and choosing a perfect name satisfying all of them is not possible.
- We as individuals also have some problems with a few names which might be due to emotions. politically, or historically. And filtering them is not possible.
- Name after election need trademark checks from the foundation as a final step and there is always a chance that winning names are filtered out so the electorate might not be happy with that. So the process is also not perfect.

Tried to solve it in many ways:
```````````````````````````````
There were a lot of proposals to solve the above issues but we could not get any agreement on either of these and live with all these issues until the Zed cycle.

https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-July/068757.html

Which AFAIK was the first time name issues happened.
Yeah, thanks I remember that now.

I don't know if that's worth to mention but often such concerns are raised even after name was already choosen (see Zed release issue 2 for example). In such case changing the name may be even harder.

Can we keep the definition in cloudkitty::params and use the value defined here ?

I know that we use the same value in all distro now, but it would help us to update when any distro change this path.

If you insist.... 
But I think we should get rid of the params class anyway and use the data (hiera) directory to configure these things in proper, current puppet style.

class inheritance is old style, used in puppet < 4.
(see https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/6.18/style_guide.html#class-inheritance)

in puppet > 4, you should use a hiera module hierarchy to set defaults. Since we require puppet > 6, we should start implementing that. It would make the code faster and better readable.

So this is a style question, the old one like you propose or the "proper, current" or let's say "modern" according to the puppet style guide.

Both styles are working, but I have a strong recomandation, that we should go forward and implement towards a modern style.

Also, does it make sense to add a new parameter for this as well ?

I see the similar fix has been merged into puppet-aodh and in that change this value was made configurable.

can do that.
Would you agree, if I use a data/hiera hierarchy to set the defaults (and remove params.pp) ?

One concern with current implementation is that it accepts "undef"  to use the default value.
I don't know how many users will try using undef actually, but since we once accept it, we might need a deprecation phase as I did in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/755140/ .

If you will never implement this with class inheritance now then it would be better to implement using hiera now, otherwise we should somehow implement something to deal with this unexpected but valid usage...
Ack, correct (or bettern, modern as we said in this discussion) would be to add a type to the parameter (String) and hiera defaults per os-family. And remove the pick below.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: We SHOULD add the ceilometer user to the libvirt group, otherwise the ceilometer user can't access libvirt daemon, which is required for ceilometer-compute.
Thanks, But I am a bit confused about this. I didn't see packages(for example ubuntu package) will add ceilometer user into libvirt/nova group. Maybe I miss something？

>  I didn't see packages(for example ubuntu package) will add ceilometer user into libvirt/nova group.

That's why we have that implementation to add the ceilometer to the nova/libvirt group.
As the packages create the ceilometer user but does not add the user to the libvirt group, deployment toolings such as puppet should take care of that membership atm.
@Takashi do you have any further comments about this change?
Looks you got another change to drop the user/group creation. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-ceilometer/+/830022 that is totally fine with me to go with this way.

The ceilometer user should be created by ceilometer-common package. The current resource definition is used to add the ceilometer user to nova/libvirt group but we do not intend to override the default package user. I'm not sure how much beneficial to let users to override uid/gid.

Thanks a lot Takashi for your detailed comments. Yeah, I agree with you that it may be better for me to create the user/groups in external manifests and adding a knob to enable/disable user/group management will be a reasonable solution. I will abandon my previous changes including this one, and will follow up your new refactor change instead. Thanks again!

The intention of the current user/group resources is to add the ceilometer user to the required groups. As in the current support scope of puppet, we expect the user/group are created by packages, exposing more interface to allow complicated user/group declaration is not desired, IMO.

Also, currently, these user/group resources are triggred after package installation. Thus the ceilometer user/group are created first with the specific uid/gid defined in package manifests during package installation, and then uid/gid are modified by the resource. This would leave the files provided by packages kept with old uid/gid. This sounds like problematic for your case, doesn't it ?

If you intend to use your own uid/gid then you should create system users/groups with desired ids first and then install packages so that package installation picks up the existing ids. The dependency required for that (create users BEFORE package installation) would conflict with what we need when we use the users created by packages.

IMO the right approach is to add a knob to disable user/group management so that you can create users/groups as you want in external manifests or external tooling.

See https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-ceilometer/+/841814 .

Thanks Takashi for your comments. 

Yes, we use puppet module in the host(VM) level to generate config files. And kolla container will mount the config files/folder during its runtime. In that case, if we keep the default kolla image uid/gid, we should use the same one to start the container from the host(VM). This is a natural transistion for us, because we are migarting our services from VM to container. And we deployed the service on VM using puppet module before and it worked well, so now we just want to start the service as a container without changing other things. 

And as you replied in another change I made (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-ceilometer/+/841528), maybe adding uid/gid as configurable parameter will be easier solution?

Sorry I was off during first week of May and missed this after coming back holidays.

Though I understand part of your thought, do you mind explaining a few more details, expecialy about the way you use the puppet module with such container deployment ? AFAIK in Kolla the users are created during building the packages, so as long as you execute puppet inside containers then you don't need this change as the puppet execution looks up the user inside container images. This is how we actually use puppet modules in TripleO and we have never seen any issue with that.

You might be able to use puppet modules to generate config files, but the current modules do not support that use case perfectly (eg. There are some packages still forcefully installed. A few configuration tasks like apache files requires the packages are installed) and I believe we still need some amount of work, which I'm not sure could be worth doing.

yeah the benefit is more about the ceilometer container deployment. Like for kolla container, the ceilometer uid/gid will by default use different value: 42405. Have the ability to override them will make container deployment easier. So how do you think of it?

specs/zed/approved/glance/glance-downloa.message:
When dealing with a multi-region cloud it often appear that operators or
customers need to copy images from a region to another, for by example:

- Copy all your public images between your regions (operator)
- Copy instance snapshot in another region to have a backup (user)
- Build your base application image from a factory in one region, then propagate it to multiple regions (user)

We can't rely on the "copy-image" import method to copy an image from a backend to another because it require the same glance endpoint so the same region which is not
our use-case here.

The only way we have to do that now is to download locally the image data and upload it elsewhere, which require some orchestration, and is a huge disk space and bandwidth loss.
The web-download workflow will remain unchanged, only difference is to retrieve the downloadable data from an other glance endpoint instead of from an arbitrary URL.
I think the end of this paragraph is covered by the "Proposed change" part
to authenticate on the remote glance we propose to use the context token of the call, so it will require to have a federated Keystone environment between the two Glance.

Can you fill in more information here? Specifically, what metadata will be brought over? What happens if the disk_format/container_format does not match? What happens if there are existing metadata items of the same name as the ones you want to import? What happens if metadata injection is configured on the target glance -- will those take precedence (I hope)?

Even though image needs to be created before import call I think you can still add metadata to image, similar to what we are doing in inject metadata plugin.

Also, can you mention somewhere in the spec that it will honour --stores,--all-stores,--allow-failure

Because in case --allow-failure is False then it will remove the data from all stores where image is already imported (should we do that for glance-download as we are copying data from another deployment, if we are going to inherit from web-download task then it is already taken care, but IMO just for awareness we should mention it specifically.)

While the metadata is important for the image to be bootable, the internal plugin handling the image payload transport is not the right place to do it. We can do that consistently in the client or in it's own part in the import taskflow, but it should not be mixed into this plugin.

For us to ever being able to consistently import images from other Glance instances with or without relying on this plugin, network access to the source cloud and federation between them, all the metadata _needs_ to be handled somewhere else.

i dont think this will be usable if we do not copy the metadata.
or rather it woudl be useable but a bad end user experice.

i also find the need to create the image ahead of time to be rather undesireable form a ux point of view.

i think the typical workflow for many is to create the image and import the data in one call.

e.g. openstack image create --file my.qcow --property hw_machine_type=q35 .... my-image


what i think we shoudl be aiming for is a design where by we make a singel call to glance on the target cloud that pass a minimal set of info that then causes the import form the souces

so something like this

openstack image create --remote-import --remote-endpoint https://glance.my.source.cloud --remote-token=$(openstack --os-cloud=src token issue -f value -c id) --remote-uuid <source uuid> <my imported image name>

that shoudl be all that is required for glance to retrive the image (data, metadta and fromat info) form the remote cloud so that it could automaticaly populate the
image and contaienr format, copy the metadta and import the image data.


that avoid the issue with failure due to in comparitble format/type as glance is respocnable for copying them. its simple to use as an end user and it should prevent unbootable images.
We were thinking that it was a good idea to not copy the metadata on plugin side as the image must be created before the import so we let the responsibility to the enduser to be in charge of that.

Can we have two plugins for this solution
1. glance-download internal import method for importing the image from another glance
2. import-metadata (or something specific) external plugin like inject metadata for importing metadata from another glance

And if glance-download method is enabled then it should have import-metadata enabled as well.

> i dont think this will be usable if we do not copy the metadata.
> or rather it woudl be useable but a bad end user experice.

Yep, agreed.

> i also find the need to create the image ahead of time to be rather undesireable form a ux point of view.

Unfortunately, that's the mechanism we have. You call import on an existing not-yet-uploaded image. That's the process we have for doing these more complex "where do I get the data" operations, so it's what we have to work with.

> i think the typical workflow for many is to create the image and import the data in one call.
> 
> e.g. openstack image create --file my.qcow --property hw_machine_type=q35 .... my-image

Actually from the user perspective this is and can be one operation, as far as the client is concerned:

 openstack image create --file my.qcow --import foo

Will do the "create an image" and "stage this file" and "import from staging" operations and the user doesn't really know (unless it fails).

> what i think we shoudl be aiming for is a design where by we make a singel call to glance on the target cloud that pass a minimal set of info that then causes the import form the souces

The internal plugin refers to _internal_plugins/ [0] that are the import methods in API/client perspective. It's piece of code that handles the image payload data to be available for the rest of the import taskflow. These are configured in the glance-api.conf enabled_import_methods. What you sean are referring to in your example are the import plugins that are various tools to introspect, modify and inject the payload and metadata options automatically during the import. We do encourage and support adding deployers own tools as needed under the plugins/ on top of the ones provided in-tree in fairly easy manner, while we do not have similar mechanism for the _internal_plugins that are more tightly integrated to the code.

https://github.com/openstack/glance/tree/master/glance/async_/flows

"internal plugin" refers to being bundled in the tree and not separately installable, AFAIK.

Also, these other plugins you mention are different and they would run, as noted, after the image is fetched via glance-download (or web-download, or uploaded with glance-direct). So what you're describing will happen properly, i.e. after glance-download pulls the image, the image conversion and metadata injection will run on it if configured.

Yeah, and that was the original plan. However, these two clouds are not part of a trust relationship, and taking a bare unrestricted token (which we store in our database) would allow the target cloud to do *anything* to the source cloud it wants while the token is valid. I could see all your images, including snapshots of sensitive things. I could reboot your instances into rescue mode and do stuff to them. I could download your cinder and swift data.

If you're an admin using this to move images to another separate cloud I could...do anything.

Federation makes that clean for now (and the people working on this are already federated). I think longer-term we need, as you noted, an "export this one image to a temp url" sort of take-out mechanism, which this can feed from just as easily.

We discussed in PTG that we would confirm disk and container matches the source image before doing the copy to avoid the transfer that we know will result in an unbootable image, so I think we should reflect that here.

I think I'm okay with either changing it during import or rejecting. Sean's point is good, but I think there's probably no way we can (currently) prevent someone from uploading or importing an image type that the cloud can't run. What we should focus on is making sure that we can run the images we should be able to run, because we have the metadata required to do so :)

Yep, agreed.

I don't actually think that app creds give us a better approach here. Based on my understanding of keystone's implementation, I don't think there's any way currently to limit those to one service, and definitely no way (in glance at least) to limit access to a single resource (image) for that credential. Glance does have image sharing, so some combination of a temporary project, credential for that, and sharing the image to that project would do it, and certainly some takeout mechanism could use that functionality internally to be less cumbersome for the user.

I think there's probably a good justification for a takeout-like approach for other services and it'd be good to have some general way to do it. However, I think that needs to be more fine-grained than "here is a credential to act as me on all parts of the source cloud for an hour". Even if it was limited to a single service (i.e. glance) I may want to move a fedora image I've cultivated out to a public cloud service, but that other cloud should not be able to see my windows images, their license keys, or snapshots of other instance I've taken which have sensitive data in them. That surely shouldn't allow access to all my nova instances, cinder/swift data, and networks and we shouldn't design a feature that encourages users to do that even if we recommend that they create a temporary project or something as insulation, IMHO.

By the way, from experience, you will want to grab the metadata from the remote side as a first thing, before you start the download. There are plenty of nova-cinder interactions that have suffered in the past from token expiration problems, when operations take a long time. If you have an hour-long token and start a very slow download of a large image from the remote, by the time it's done it's very possible that your token will have expired before you have a chance to grab the metadata. The easy solution to that is to grab the quick stuff first, then start the long download.

node 1 --> 172.18.0.0/16 via 10.0.1.1

Yep, each node need have its own tap device. The ECMP route is for High Available and High Performance, each node has its own kube-proxy and this kube-proxy is identical, so kuryr can forward the traffic to any host node. it user add a third host node, the route should like this:

Well, I think I understand your menas. But I still have some confusion for your comment. The document's main purpose is how to use raw kube-proxy with kuryr, means that this document should focus on the traffic that pod to service to pod. The traffic of pod to pod (don't pass through k8s service) needn't kuryr make any special process, right? This should is a neutron's issue, so we needn't illustrate it here.

This is a L3 traffic diagram. So I ignore the L2 traffic processing, this shouldn't be this document's concern, I tried to add L2 network element to it, but then the graph would be bloated. Maybe, I should rename `host node1` to `host node` in this graph, this might clear up potential ambiguity.
Well, the provider network type has no effect for this traffic path, vlan is also ok. This is ACTIVE-ACTIVE architecture, just need one host node process the traffic forward.

this is not about N/S (provider) traffic but about E/W. And if pod1 is in different node than pod2, they need to go through a geneve (for ovn) or vxlan (for ovs) tunnel. In your example you represent host node1, but not host node2
allow address pairs is for IPs, not for subnets AFAIK. Perhaps this tap device should have security disabled instead

coredump.conf is replaced automatically by the parameters defined in the puppet erb template (coredump.conf.erb) through the runtime. swift/common/memcached.py.message:
hmmm, or perhaps ignore_errors=True ?

I even wonder if I'd prefer a new method let set_or_fail - with hindsight, the current set/get might be safe_set/safe_get
this should also raise an exception

why do we not continue? is there an assumption that if the value fails with one server then it will fail with all? if the value is too large then that is reasonable,  but can there be other reasons to fail in this way?

or is the lack of continue unintended?

It was definitely a limitation I was thinking about -- as an auth system, I kinda want things to work agains the primary location or not at all. If I try to store an auth token, fail to set the primary, but succeed at a secondary location, it's not clear we should tell clients about the token -- on subsequent use, we may be able to talk to the primary again, get a cache miss, and respond 401 despite having a "fresh" token.

Conversely, if I try to check a token, fail at the primary, then get a cache miss at the secondary, should we actually 401? Or should we 503 and hope the primary is around next time (or the load balancer gets the client to a proxy that *can* talk to the primary)? I suppose the 401's probably fairly justifiable in this case (it's not so different from memcache restarting on the primary or something).
How about raising a MemcacheConnectionError to be consistent with incr and decr and so that callers are spared the implementation details?
The more I think about it, incr() makes me nervous... with overloaded servers, you could call incr() 10 times, but on get()s have some weird smear of sometimes getting 6, or 3, or 1...
the errors we have seen in production are while connecting to servers in _get_conns(), so no servers are yielded to this loop and the except clause at line 385 is not reached
we may also want to upgrade delete and the multi-* methods, but not necessarily in this patch

This seems unnecessarily complex if we always pass in self.__repr__() which is formatting the string for us. Can we instead simply accept the string and set it as an attribute which we return as the __repr__ of the Attributes object?

As an alternative Attributes() is meant to be a safe to string format set of attributes related to a broader object. It is possible that broader object's internal __repr__ isn't safe for external consumption?

We might want to instead track which attributes are set on this object and then do a simple foo={foo} repr to ensure we only expose these safe attributes?

OK, this doesn't work because we install tempest globally with pip_install (which uses sudo -- i.e. source dir must be owned by root) but then we're running tox here as stack -- tox tries to install tempest into the tox venv and now wants it as "stack", the user.

I see no way around having to either setup multiple checkouts of the code, or constantly chowning the source tree.  Both are beyond silly for this case, and I really think upstream needs to think a bit more about the implications of the change...

I believe the save on 166 is actually what saves the image.status=ACTIVE, as if I comment out that line, the image never exits saving state.

I will post here as well, but I will work on a spec for this, unfortunately I don't know when I'll have time

We talked about this at PTG, but here's a summary:

We're good with this proceeding in general, but we should have a spec to cover the plan. Specifically, we should make this pull the properties from the same config location as the import plugin so there are not two lists. The setting of the properties should be done during image upload, ideally at the end, and before the image is placed into active state. Just like the import plugin, it should overwrite any such properties that were set by the user on the image before the injection happens.

nit: we can remove "with" and go with "assert_called_once()"

It's not the same thing, the assert_called_once method is the same as self.assertEqual(1, proxy.flatten.call_count), so it doesn't check the arguments.

By using the assert_called_once_with method I'm ensuring not only that it's only called once, but also that no arguments were passed on the call.

You can confirm this in the python interpreter:

   $ python3

   >>> from unittests import mock
   >>> m = mock.Mock()
   >>> m.test(1,2)

   >>> m.test.assert_called_once()

   >>> m.test.assert_called_once_with()
   Traceback (most recent call last):

Well, The router used to connect to each namespace subnets should belong to a special project, the kuryr user belong to the service project and have admin role, so the kuryr has ability to make the namespace subnet connect to the communal router. Yeah, restricting that to namespaces works in my perspective as you can just set client's RBAC to not allow editing namespace. Now an interesting implication of this is that Kuryr tries to add each of the namespaces subnets to a router. Do you plan to make that router accessible for all the tenants?

Thinking more - this might be required. One of the K8s API contracts is availability of the default `kubernetes` Services to all pods. In order to achieve that you'd probably need to make sure there's connectivity to the services subnet.

Oh, services subnet would need to be public too, as Kuryr always creates the LBs in it, regardless of the tenant used. We can't work around this as it's K8s who's doing IPAM for Services.

specs/keystone/backlog/reparent-projects.message: If someone is ready to take on this work this cycle, please propose it under the ussuri/ directory instead of backlog/.
Can the new parent be a domain?

This isn't very RESTful, is there a reason to have this /reparent action instead of allowing a PATCH to update parent_id?

Adam's original proposal used a keystone-manage command instead of exposing it as an API, could you document the reason not to do it that way in the alternatives section?

I want to clarify, this is intended to be system-administrator-specific, right?

I worry about an edge case where users might inject projects into domains they're not a member of.
Since projects can already have a domain as a parent I would also expect another domain to be allowed as a new parent.

A PATCH on the existing API was my original idea, but I thought a new API would allow us a 'noop' style function built into it, and I believe it is also what Morgan and others suggested as safer.

I'll add a note eventually about why we decided against the cli variant, but the short version is:
A cli implementation implies operator access and realistically this kind of action is handled by account managers or people who may have admin access to the cloud, but not the hosts. It also was originally proposed as a cli which couldn't be done live, or with an active project. An API gives us the most sane long term support, in a place a cloud admin (or system scope user) can access, with sane programmitically parsable responses for a noop style check.

I don't know. Is there any terrible implication to allowing projects to move domains? I can't think of one, and I bet there are useful cases to allowing a project to move to another domain provided the name isn't already taken there.

Scoping for any users who used to use that project may break until they update the project_domain, but that's all I can imagine. Roles work, users don't change, and resources don't care about the domain that I know of.

I know in our case, if we could move projects across domains, it would mean we could one day go to giving each new customer their own domain, and in the process migrate any existing customers to that.
Yes, this should only ever be admin/system only. The expectation is a VERY powerful API, with a way to see the effects it may have (role changes), and allow an admin with knowledge to do the changes.
++ let's make sure it's spelled out that this new API is specific to system-admins.
maybe nitpicky but I would prefer "current_parent" or "old_parent"
current_parent sounds sane
Did we discuss exposing some kind of noop/dry-run API to help with this?
The GET method for this new API would be the noop/dry-run with a full update of the role changes related to the move.

We should drop the cache (assignment, resource, token?) when we perform a move.

If a project is cached within a specific domain or parent, and it's moved to another part of the hierarchy, a user of the project could get stale assignments, couldn't they?

I guess this is how I'm thinking about it:

 - project B has a parent project A
 - user bob has an inherited admin role assignment on project A
 - system admin jane moves project B to domain Bar
 - user bob can still get tokens for project B (?)

Should that be the intended behavior?

Actually, that brings up another question. How should this feature handle inherited role assignments? Do they continue to exist?

Is there any effect this would have on resources associated with projects? I think not, as the project ID wouldn't be changing?

What effect would this have on recalculating project limits as implemented in the /v3/limits API? What effect would it have on current implementations for flat or hierarchical quota calculations in eg. nova or cinder?

We should do some testing, but other than Keystone, none of the project are really aware of the project tree. Resources are owned by the 'current' project not the parent, so nothing should happen to them.

I'd need to look at the limits implementations and confirm, but there would likely have to be some recalculations. Not to mention if this project's limits are higher than the tree it is being moved to, that should raise some sort of error upfront. 

If this project has resources which are greater than the limits in the new tree, then we can't really do much to check that can we? The usage is only known to Nova/Cinder/etc, and we shouldn't query that. So it can happen that you reparent a project only to then run into a 11/10 used quota situation, and I'd hope in those cases Nova and the like handle it like a quota that is already full (which I think they just do).
Did we have other PTG/forum discussions on this or mailing list discussions?

There are some related to resource ownership, which I don't particularly think are relevant. Most of this proposal came about from discussions with Morgan and Adam in Berlin, and further IRC chats I think.
Is this a duplicate of "existing_inherited" from line 76?

I don't think it was meant to be... I think it was meant to be existing_effective minus the 'direct' assignments potentially to showcase assignments coming from inheritance up the tree.

I'm also missing here:
new_effective which should be what roles will automatically inherit down to the new location.
It's not clear to me how that's represented in "existing" and "existing_inherited"
I'm gonna restructure this example response. It doesn't make sense to me anymore.
need to drop both of these since as far as I'm aware neither are still around in OpenStack. :(
Done

As below, I think it is more consistent with how we perform other operations if the new parent id is in the URL.

v3/projects/{project_id}/reparent/<parent_uuid>

As that parameter is essential to the query and operations.

I think that's fair, but the reasoning in behind having it be optional was that sometimes you may not know where you plan on moving a project yet, and want to just see what roles will transfer with it. This would give you a preview of what might happen. Having a new parent target be required isn't entirely a bad thing though.
Suspect it would make more sense to have the new parent ID here in the URL and make this a PUT.
That works too, and PUT probably makes more sense given this is and update to a project rather than a create.

The user performing the reparent should not need to have the Admin role at a system level, but instead should be allowed to perform the operation if they have admin on both the source and target projects.

I'm alright with this, but the system level requirement came about because of a fear of this being too powerful or 'dangerous'. I think this kind of operation is important to be able to manage projects though, so the having it less 'admin' and more project admin level focused is better in my view, and I feel that the GET API here puts the onus of not screwing up on the person using the API rather than us limiting a useful thing for fear of them shooting themselves in the foot.

specs/stein/approved/glance/glance-cachi.message: How is this enforced?

The new code being proposed, i.e. for handling this new 'data access' solution for Glance where image and image-metadata can be retrieved (and cached) from a remote Glance, will only issue GET calls to the remote Glance.
So the proposal is to introduce intentional continuous split brain situation?

The idea is that the only way to create an image in the central cloud will be to specifically issue a request against the central cloud glance.

The edge cloud glance will pull the image from the central cloud if someone asks for it, in effect acting as a local cache for the central glance images; ... as well as allowing the creation of additional local-only images.

As the UUID is the only supported identification in glance I don't think this is acceptable intentional behavior. Image search won't solve the issue of UUID collision when it's matter of 2 different images.

Agree this is ugly.

I am debating whether to allow the creation of additional local-only images at the Edge Cloud.  It is not absolutely required. And, in fact, our pre-upstreaming code, did not allow this.

The only way to possibly resolve this would be to disallow creation of images at the edge with the same UUID as an image in the Central Cloud ... but even that has issues as that check can not be done when edge cloud is disconnected from central cloud and don't want to have to change central cloud glance to have to do a UUID check of edge clouds when creating images.   Maybe assign unique UUID-prefixes for the creation of UUIDs on individual clouds ... ugh, seems like a lot of effort for a 'nice to have' type functionality.

ok ... seriously thinking of removing the capability of creating local-only images at the Edge Cloud.

I might be missing something here.

Where/how is the metadata cached for these newly cached images from the remote glance?

What is taking care of the cache invalidation and cleanup?

If malicious image is cached to the edge site and connection is cut how can one deal with it when no modifications are allowed?

Same with the image membership. Is it just assumed that user which is not anymore allowed access to an image is ok to boot such in the disconnected edge site?

Will add text that indicates that any time the edge cloud goes to use an image from the remote glance (i.e. get (and cache), use from cache, etc. ), the edge cloud will try to pull the image-metadata from the remote glance and update the cached copy of the image-metadata if it has changed.

Wrt Cache invalidation and cleanup mechanisms ... will update text to
indicate that Edge Cloud always validates that Image still exists on
Central Cloud before checking if Image itself is already cached locally,
in order to avoid the expensive image download.  If the Image does not
exist in the Central Cloud, then the cached image and its metadata, if
they exist, are removed from cache.

Wrt dealing with malicious image that is cached, this can not be dealt
with until central connection is restored, and malicious image is
removed from Central Cloud and cache invalidation/cleanup mechanisms

Yes purely on demand.

The edge user does a command like 'nova boot ... A-image ... ', 
- edge nova requests image from edge glance, 
- edge glance forwards nova's message to central glance, 
- central glance responds to edge glance,
- edge glance caches and forwards response on to nova.

Thank you for clarification folks. That was me getting the "Registering for synchronisation" https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/MappingOfUseCasesFeaturesRequirementsAndUserStories#Registering_for_synchronisation wrong and extending that into the wrong assumptions of that the Distributed Control Plane didn't make it into MVP as there going to be no tooling for advanced data replication with conflicts resolving. So even though the latter statement happened to be true, that still allows us to proceed with DCP at least for Glance and Keystone!

There are two deployment scenarios identified by the edge-computing group.  See https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Edge_Computing_Group/Edge_Reference_Architectures#Distributed_Control_Plane_Scenario .

One scenario with a distributed control plane and one scenario with a centralized control plane.  The requirement to be tolerant to connection loss with the central cloud is related to the distributed control plane scenario where there is a full control plane at the edge cloud.

When disconnected from the central cloud, the edge cloud glance in the distributed control plane scenario will be able to support GETs on its cached image and image meta-data.

This general requirement for tolerance to connection loss to the central cloud has been explicitly discussed in the edge-computing group and is why we have included both the distributed and central scenarios in the MVP.  We have identified Use Cases where this is required ... e.g. Distributed Cloud solutions where the edge clouds provide compute power for complex hospital equipment such as MRIs.  The Distributed Cloud solution is being used to provide centralized management of the various edge cloud deployments across a geographically disperse hospital campus.  Loss of connectivity to the Central Cloud can not prevent the edge cloud -based hospital equipment from being able to start new applications, scale applications or recover failed applications.

ditto, a single central control plane have no autonomy supported, which is no CRUDs allowed for isolated edge sites, for MVP. How can this be achieved then? Let's please adapt this spec for real MVP requirements for the control plane.

This specification is in alignment with the MVP architecture defined by the OpenStack edge-computing group, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Edge_Computing_Group/Edge_Reference_Architectures#Distributed_Control_Plane_Scenario

So, the edge glance uses a glance database in the normal way, and the periodic task populates the local images and data after it runs, is that right?

On day zero, does the periodic pull all images and their metadata? Or does it just pull information about them, and only pull the actual image if/when asked locally? The former sounds like a startup storm problem. The latter probably makes the most sense, but it also requires a well-performing pipeline that streams the image from the remote central glance to the local disk for caching as well as to the synchronously-waiting requestor. Might be worth calling that out somewhere so it's clear. Downloading the image to disk, then serving it to the waiting requestor is not likely to work for anything other than trivial images (and/or without substantial changes to things like Nova, AFAIK).

Definitely no DB replication. It says below that edge glance will only communicate with central glance via REST. That's why it should be totally doable to make the edge glance quite self-sufficient from the start.

The Edge Glance will use the glance database for caching of image metadata.  The 'source of truth' for the Edge Glance API is the central Glance DB.  When disconnected from the central Glance, the Edge Glance will use the glance database in the normal way.

The Edge Glance will cache the image and image-metadata from the central Glance, when an image is asked for via the Edge Glance API.

The purpose of the periodic task is to simply capture any changes to image-metadata at the Central Glance, for ONLY images/metadata that have "already" been locally cached at the Edge Glance. 

The existing upstream Glance Caching already implements a well-performing pipeline where the image stream is split/replicated with one stream goes to the image cache and the other stream goes to the entity that requested the image.  ( I will highlight that this is the case in my next update to the document )
So this implies no database replication for the central and edge glance instances, right?

In this initial implementation, you will not be able to create snapshots at the edge.

I will specify this in next update of document.

I'm okay with snapshots not being possible while the parent is unavailable for the first cut. However, if everything is working, it seems rather unfortunate to not be able to do snapshots.

Even if everything in the edge is fully ephemeral, snapshots can be important for forensics. Consider this case: something fails, so you shoot it in the head and re-deploy. However, the same problem keeps happening, so the next time it occurs, you snapshot it before you redeploy so you can grab the snapshot and examine offline.

Okay that seems like a really big deal to me, just FYI.

Why not just make POST pass through like a proxy to the parent glance? Then you can grab the image as it streams through and not have to pull it down again (assuming you proxy a 200 back from the parent).

Does this mean that every time I do a nova boot in the edge cloud, that nova hits the edge glance, which makes a blocking call to the central glance before it can reply to nova? That seems like it will not be great for performance, as well as potentially have the problem of cascading timeouts (where nova has a 60s timeout against its glance, which has a 60s timeout against the central glance, etc). It also impacts the "works while disconnected" statement. Even if you have a short timeout between edge glance and central glance, and gracefully fall back to the cached data, you introduce a $timeout delay into all that stuff.

If you're going to do a periodic audit, why not just refresh the image metadata then?

Agree, I like the idea of just using the periodic audit to refresh the image metadata, makes sense.

Wrt the issue that while disconnected, you will always be impacted by the edge glance --> central glance timeout, ... a possible solution is to use the periodic audit to manage a central-glance-connectivity status which is used by the edge glance API to immediately determine whether communication with central glance should be attempted or not.

Or use a short connection timeout and a long lifetime timeout so that you notice a failure to connect quickly, but still have long-term protection over the connection stalling. Also, if you do the TTL thing, then you don't have to hit the parent in a lot of cases.
Presumably a list with a changes-since filter to make this efficient? Every edge glance doing a GET of each image periodically is a lot of traffic.
Seems like any real cloud is going to need that for baseline decent performance. Hundreds of edge sites all hitting the central glance for hundreds of images is.. a lot of traffic.
Agree, the GLANCE Reviewer suggested the same thing ... I was leaving it as an option to explore in our implementation, but will explicitly indicate it here in next update of SPEC.

How about a TTL in the image metadata which instructs the edge glance how long an image can be considered good without refreshing? That way we could only hit the central repo that often to refresh stuff. Wide-access images which are unlikely to see substantial change could have long TTL values. Images for which metadata should be refreshed on each boot (potentially even denying handing out the cached image if the metadata cannot be confirmed with central) could have a TTL of zero.

Interesting idea.
Let me discuss with Glance Team.

IMHO, spell this out for our not-native English speaking friends.
Agree

I like this idea too ... might be a little tricky to implement based on our current thinking ... but will document in SPEC that we will explore this in the implementation.

Return 500? It's not *really* a total service failure; other requests may work fine.

Return 404? It may or may not be a valid image and what a downstream service does with a 404 might be different than what it really means.

Return 503? The service is available, just that one resource isn't.

Anyway, personally, I'd like to see those called out.
I'll add at least the major APIs ... so reader has a view of generally how we will handle the typical error scenarios.

This seems to imply that you're going to do the download first, and then serve the waiting requestor. I definitely think that should be avoided if possible. I think the "all nova boots fail until the first download finishes" behavior won't be very nice. Also consider the *second* nova boot at day zero. Consider:

 1. Compute node A requests image foo
 2. Edge Glance starts downloading foo, Compute node A waits synchronously
 3. Compute node B requests image foo ....

At #3, you want to not start requesting the image again, and ideally not return "500, Sorry not ready yet". You could start streaming the image that is showing up on disk to the remote (tail-f style) as long as you can know when to EOF. Worth calling out what the plan for that is here I think.

Cool, glad to hear that's already something we can lean on. Calling that out specifically to avoid the impression (which I got several times here) that it'll be a sequential dance.

So that brings a small amount of additional latency in the happy path, but hopefully not too much in the grand scheme of downloading a many-GB image.

As mentioned previously, the existing upstream Glance Caching already implements a well-performing pipeline where the image stream is split/replicated with one stream goes to the image cache and the other stream goes to the entity that requested the image.  

Will at least update document to say that this border case will be tested.

I don't know about the glance team, but in a nova spec we would want these to be tempest or functional tests. I would hope that this work would yield a job (either new, or modification of an existing one) that runs an edge glance against a real one and ensures the behaviors you expect to work actually do. Is that planned?

Also, this arrangement should totally work in a situation where you have an edge glance pointed at another edge glance, which in turn points at the real one. It'd be nice to validate that such an arrangement works, and doesn't regress as we move from the initial implementation to one that works for more cases. I would think that sort of daisy-chained arrangement would be rather common, so we might as well make sure it's tested from the get-go, IMHO.

I'll discuss with Glance Team what they typically expect in this test section.

I'll document the notion that this should work in the daisy-chained scenario ... as at least a future capability.
so it worths noting that database are supposed only to be switched and never replicated (shared-nothing)

Yes, the Edge Cloud Glance DB is simply a Read Only Cache of a subset of the Central Cloud Glance DB; a subset based on what images have been pulled by the Edge Cloud Glance.

I'll clarify in next update of SPEC.

As the edge cloud's Glance will NOT support creation of local images, how would we propagate the image deletion event to the central cloud, including its temporary unavailability cases, so it follows up with that, like via eventual synchronization, and removes that image in its DB?

Note, DELETE'ing at the edge cloud glance contradicts the statement below: "POST, PUT and DELETE APIs at the edge cloud Glance, the error will be 405 (Method Not Allowed)"
Agree, the local Edge Cloud DELETE operation would semantically just be flushing that image & image-metadata from the Local Edge Cloud's cache.

> As the edge cloud's Glance will NOT support creation of local
 > images, how would we propagate the image deletion event to the
 > central cloud, including its temporary unavailability cases, so it
 > follows up with that, like via eventual synchronization, and
 > removes that image in its DB?

We wouldn't. A DELETE at a caching-only glance would be a deletion of the cached information, not the image. It's a quick way to invalidate the cache at a certain level. If that's because we've already deleted the actual image in the parent glance, then an attempt to boot will fail to re-populate the cache here. If the cache delete was just to refresh (or something) then a new boot will re-cache the image.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What is the value of having the chroots live in persistent storage? I would have thought they only need to exist inside the pkgbuild container. Just curious.

Put the chroots into the persistent storage can avoid the great effort of repeated chroots creation. Currently chroots loading/saving mechanism is used to load the already created chroots from persistent storage or save the first created chroots to the external persistent storage.

Could this be made optional? If using the build in a K8s environment you may not have easy access to persistent storage. The containers may live for a long time, so the penalty would only exist for a short time, no?

Yes, the frequency of the penalty happening depends on the frequency of the container restarting. If it assumes that there are no any persistent shared volumes and the container lives for a long time, it's ok to put all chroots and their config files to the container's non-persistent fs.
But this may requires totally changing of the current interactive mode between builder and pkgbuilder for these log files(the log of chroot creating, the log of package building) can't be accessed and showed on builder's screen.
I had not thought about the implications to interactive mode. OK. I am fine with this progressing as is but at some point we might have to implement a change to make this optional.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: A few issues. I will give it another read through after a new version is posted. Thanks.

The is a 'big' upgrade for pkgbuilder from single chroot building to multiple chroots buildings which can support 'real' parallel building instances. Current the default parallel building instances are 4.
And this commit will not impact the original serial building mode.

OK, I will updated with all your comments and do the verification again, then the new version will be posted.
Before that let me make some explain for some design things among your comments.
Just answer some questions related with the design thinking first. The other code changes will be done and verified again, then new version will be posted.

I have concerns with how this is going to work when there are multiple instances of the pkgbuilder, remember we have to think about both the individual developer (minikube) case and the organization builds (full k8s, multiple instances of containers) cases. Using non-persistent data this would not be an issue but using persistent storage you will have to ensure that folders use unique identifiers...
Haiqing, thanks for the additional information, this helps.

Thanks Mark, actually there are only one pkgbuilder service, but multiple sbuild instances that each one is running on the user specific chroot with name <distro>-<arch>-<user>, the workflow is like below:


For serial build:
==================
Build request from builder client         |     Pkgbuilder handle

   Request to build
--------------------------------------->      ---> Confirm that the default chroot
 (parameters: /USER/PROJECT/Package)               "bullseye-amd64-<USER>" exists                           
                                                   on the persistent storage                           
                                                   /localdisk/pkgbuilder/ or
                                                   create it if it does not exist
                                              ---> Create sbuild process to build            
                                                   package on the user's chroot:
                                                   "sbuild -c bullseye-amd64-<USER> 
                                                    <Package>"
                                              <--- Reply with the path of build log 
                                                   on shared volume
Show the build log on builder's screen



For parallel build:
===================
Build request from builder client         |     Pkgbuilder handle

   Request to build
--------------------------------------->      ---> Confirm that the default chroot
 (parameters: /USER/PROJECT/Packages)              "bullseye-amd64-<USER>" exists                           
                                                   on the persistent storage                           
                                                   /localdisk/pkgbuilder/ or
                                                   create it if it does not exist
                                                   Then try to clone 4 chroots with 
                                                   the default chroot, the naming 
                                                   rule is: bullseye-amd64-<USER>-  
                                                   {1,2,3,4}
                                              ---> While (Packages):
                                                   --> Apply one free chroot 
                                                   --> Create sbuild process:
                                                       "sbuild -c bullseye-amd64- 
                                                        <USER>-{1,2,3,4} Package
                                              <--- Reply with the path of build 
                                                   logs on shared volume

Show these build logs on builder's screen and monitor which build is done

   Clean require
-------------------------------------->     ---> Clean and free the chroots


You can see from the working flow, the chroots and the folders are unique identified.

to fix.

Perhaps rename the rc file and change your Dockerfile to reference the new path.  That at least will tell docker it can't use it's cached copy.

I'm having a lot of difficulty testing this.

I had to 'stx-nit-env --nuke' my old environment, AND 'docker image rm' all traces of my old images, AND 'stx-nit-env --rebuild'.

Without these steps the rebuilt docker images would use cached layers from previous builds that resulted in a broken environment.

I don't think the designers that type 'repo sync' should be rewarded with a trashed build environment, and then the need to take extraordinary and unfamiliar recovery actions.

Please think carefully about a safe transition for users that have pre-existing environments.

Thanks your test,  since all the stuff of pkgbuilder including the configure files will be copied into docker image, so "./stx-init-env --rebuild" is manually required, of course, the docker image of pkgbuilder should be updated and pull to the hub again. It's my oversight to not mention this in the commit messages. Actually this commit requires to start from a totally clean env.

There is a mistake for "stx/toCOPY/builder/buildrc", this change should be put into 
https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/root/+/831330 for the code split.

As far as your 'repo sync' comments, my original design is to replace the service scripts and configure files of pkgbuilder with the code in 'tools' repo, like replacing "/opt/{app.py,debbuiler.py,setup.sh,debbuilder.conf}" with <MY_REPO_ROOT_DIR>/<stx-tools/stx/toCopy/pkgbuilder/{app.py, debbuilder.py,setup.sh,debbuilder.conf}>, in this way, the docker image of pkgbuilder need not to be rebuilt with each minor or major changes on the code of pkgbuilder,but this make the pkgbuilder's service depends on the shared volume and the builder's behavior, and can not be a independent service for multiple user's access in future, so I have to back to follow the old way, so any changes on the code need to be rebuilt the docker image. 
Of course, we can make pkgbuilder to do what builder container do, after the pkgbuilder container starting, run 'repo init/sync' to download its service scripts and config files, but I think this is unsuited to pkgbuilder which is more like a micro service, not a interactive container like builder container.
In the latest patch set, the update in "stx/toCOPY/builder/buildrc" has been dropped, but still need to 'stx-init-env --reubild' to rebuild the docker image of pkgbuilder.

switching add_task from GET to POST was the first error I hit.
Docker used the cached version of this file from my old environment.
Thus I got 'unsupported method' when a POST request arrived, but only GET was supported.

In general, toCOPY files need to be renamed if the introduce non-backward compatible changes like this.  This would trigger DOCKER to re-evaluate that layer, rather than using the cache.

Another step I suggest is retaining the old add_task, and instead create add_task_parallel.  On the user side, if add_task_parallel is not available, revert to add_task.  On the backend, add_task needs to do something that at least appears to function like the old interface.
